summary: This document is a series of email exchanges from 2019-2020 between U.S. Attorney's Office personnel requesting and approving travel for the Epstein investigation (2018R01618). The emails detail planned trips to interview witnesses and victims in locations including Pensacola, Los Angeles, West Palm Beach, and Stockholm, Sweden.

persons.name: Edward Tyrrell
persons.role: Supervisor/Approving Official at U.S. Attorney's Office
persons.context: Recipient and approver of multiple travel approval requests for the Epstein investigation team. He is addressed as 'Ed' and grants approvals.

persons.name: Alex
persons.context: Primary requester of travel approvals for the Epstein investigation team to conduct witness and victim interviews in various locations. Signs off as an Assistant U.S. Attorney for the Southern District of New York.

persons.name: Maurene
persons.context: Frequently mentioned as a team member traveling with Alex or Alison to conduct interviews for the Epstein investigation in Florida and California.

persons.name: Alison
persons.context: Frequently mentioned as a team member traveling with Alex or Maurene to conduct interviews for the Epstein investigation, including victim interviews.

persons.name: Darlene Alleyne
persons.context: Consistently copied on the travel approval request emails, indicating her involvement in the administrative or oversight aspects of the Epstein investigation.

persons.name: Cynthia Perez
persons.context: Copied on some of the travel approval request emails, indicating administrative involvement.

persons.name: Michele Duncan
persons.context: Copied on several of the travel approval request emails, indicating administrative involvement.

connections.description: Alex submits travel approval requests to Edward Tyrrell, who approves them, indicating a supervisor-subordinate or approver-requester relationship within the U.S. Attorney's Office.
Frequently travel together as part of the investigation team to conduct interviews for the Epstein case.
Frequently travel together as part of the investigation team to conduct interviews for the Epstein case.
Referenced as traveling together for victim interviews as part of the investigation team.
Darlene Alleyne is consistently copied on Alex's travel requests, indicating a reporting or administrative coordination relationship.

events.title: Witness Interview in Pensacola
events.description: Planned interview of a witness in Pensacola, Florida, as part of the Epstein investigation. Travel requested for Alex and Maurene.

events.title: International Witness Interview in Sweden
events.description: Planned interview near Stockholm, Sweden, indicating the international scope of the Epstein investigation. The 'team' was slated to travel.

events.title: Interview(s) in Los Angeles
events.description: Planned interview or interviews in Los Angeles, California, for the Epstein investigation.

events.title: Interview in West Palm Beach
events.description: Planned interview in West Palm Beach, Florida. The trip was for Alex and Maurene, with a request to reserve a conference room.

events.title: Victim Interview in Los Angeles
events.description: Planned victim interview in Los Angeles, California. The team composition included Alex, Alison, and/or Maurene.

events.title: Meetings and Victim Interviews in West Palm Beach
events.description: Planned travel for meetings and victim interviews in West Palm Beach, Florida. Team composition was to be Alex and Alison or Alison and Maurene.

keyFacts: The document references the ongoing federal investigation 'United States v. Epstein, 2018R01618', described as 'an investigation relating to enticement of minors for sexual activity'.
Investigation travel spanned domestic (Florida, California) and international (Sweden) locations for witness and victim interviews between 2019 and 2020.
The investigation team, including AUSA Alex and investigators Alison and Maurene, frequently requested and used hotel conference rooms to conduct interviews.
Travel approvals were managed through a formal process within the U.S. Attorney's Office for the Southern District of New York, with Edward Tyrrell as the primary approver.
The emails show a pattern of investigative activity focused on gathering testimony, with a notable planned international trip to Sweden in January 2020.
